topic.title: #IDEAsPlatform  #UserStoryHub
topic.body:
Internet is a Brain. It needs a Mind to start thinking. I see thoughts being shaped on the web. They are yet illusions, but soon they will become decisions.
Talk with me and I'll explain more. My Gratitudes

topic.title: How did you start a new group? Instead of just a topic I mean.
Dark theme for ZeroHello and major ZeroNet sites. #UserStoryHub
topic.body:
Show how much you need it.
My eyes are sore! #GoingDark

topic.body:

Give your suggestion where on the main page of ZeroTalk it can be.

1521962808_1He5bfTsvbUXQXp5HCuKLdYutSiqD.body:
> [sylvaine](#comment_42_1F9qtxgSgbkeJX7NT2BARwR8XCn1XP4qPG): Actually, now that I think about it .. It'll happen on its own. You can't force something to go viral or popular. Like memes, if something can deliver .. and doesn't mislead or disappoint the user ... then it'll have widespread adoption. ZeroNet so far delivers pretty well. There's still a lot of work to be done.. filling it up with content should be the priority, I'd say .. now that we've hacked the shit out of everything. These days I actually feel far less motivated by financial gain, donations, blah blah blah.. and far more motivated by becoming a part of history. Fighting for a cause. ..to the point where I kinda regret the ideas I had in the past of introducing financial motives and crypto-mining into ZeroNet. I've grown to hate money over the years. It's about time we became a post-scarcity civilization. Money is only a motivator when you're starving and need to put food on the table .. but if all of your basic needs are met, then you'll likely work and create stuff just to feel a sense of belonging .. a sense of community. To be noticed.

I agree that ZeroNet needs lots of content.
I also suggest a cookie based ZeroNet technology that normal sites can use. So their server costs would be at least 10 times smaller, or even hundreds of times less costly.
What do you think?

> [achinese](#comment_40_1CuFXko1Q3MMRkboFygeu9DxNVAFG67S3q): I'm not sure about zeronet replacing normal hosting. I can rent a shared hosting at a very cheap price and advertise its domain name. Then anyone can visit it. I built a new zerosite a few days ago, buy people still cannot visit it because no peers! Even I saw my site got 40 peers. People still cannot find it. How disappointed!

What is your site? 40 peers and your statement don't make sense.

1530187949_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnX.body: Is there the ability to allow other admins, besides the owner, add to the filter list?

> [styromaniac](#comment_163_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): http://127.0.0.1:43110/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post/1oranGeS2xsKZ4jVsu9SVttzgkYXu4k9v/16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd/1518054468 [...]

We must stop cp from growing in decentralized networks.
Thanks for the efforts.

> [ssdifnskdjfnsdjk](#comment_328_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS): I do not think so, you can ask the developer (nofish). Currently i think the site owner can give out the site private signing key to other trusted people so they can also update the site or delete existing entries. But giving out such key means full ownership/editting of the site. Other option is that you send the links to site owner and he add them for you after checking.

It is useful to have filtering networks of people.
https://alternativeTo.net came to my mind. It's not totally related, but it's a useful crowdsourced method.


> [styromaniac](#comment_170_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): It appears to be very easy to clone, edit and publish. I didn't get to the publish part yet because I can't open a port on cellular data.

But it would be extra work. I suggest we make collaboration easy, and build local networks of trust.
Locality here means a bunch of people who mind the same cause.

Now imagine a place when you have an idea, you wouldn't think I can't implement it. You can save it at your name, and find the people who can use them, and even need your ideas.

1540253415_139zVkd4AsZqs9qSYk6ypPDAqDcjP.body:
Post quotes that you found very useful, in the pragmatic field of prosperity.

Pragmatism: Stuff that apply to real life. Practical, opposed to theoretical gibberish.

Prosperity: Richness in life, in all aspects. Opposed to poverty, which is the root of suffering.
(A person with lots of money can lack a prosperous life, and thus be a strong source of poverty.)

1541031054_1ByuWDrDpJKEB5WbR7Dw4CUT1pw5D.body:
> [eightyfour](#comment_7_191jbK3GNmVritcMymKkFuxyYFXxqv2xpC): This isn't censorship, the owner - or someone with access to their computer - took the site down. When more people are using ZeroNet such things will become more difficult because people will be archiving/cloning sites more. Automatic archiving could be an interesting feature to implement, but most people don't want to set the required diskspace aside, so it should be opt-in only.

Can we make the sites act like git does? For those who choose to keep all versions of them via git.

> [thunder33345](#comment_293_1AHEQxyRG9s6owyJHShB4U4rg9GL5FMX5K): i think this needs another plugin that records the site changes into giti am pretty sure this has been talked about, now i wonder how many incidents before this is developedi am thinking of something like that PLUS a way for people to share/request older copies automatically if peers choose to make their archive public

__________________________________________________________________________

I have another idea for hubs like ZeroMe. totally unrelated to our discussion.
Instead of loading via public key and the signed data of the owner of the key;
Imagine the data being hashed, and the hash of the Data is the link of the site.

for example look at this data structure:

site0 = {
Original site described
genesis hash = 0
intro: ZeroMe, a dec social network.
original author: author0 = {public key, data about the author}
source and content: html, css, json, js (I'll call this package as 'content' hereafter.)
} –> produce hash0

now the author wants to update the content. makes new site:

site1 = {
previous hash = hash0
no intro
current author: author0
updated content
} –> produce hash1, sign by author0 key, inject to the network

updates happen and site reaches site(n-1).
now imagine the author loses the key, dies, or ends the project, etc.
many people are still on the network.
here author01 comes to play

site(n) = {
previous hash = hash(n-1)
current author: author1 = {public key, data about the author}
updated content
} –> produce hash(n)

suggest the update to the structure of ZeroMe to the whole network.
since the update is needed, and no one has been around for a while,
the network is large enough to investigate the update and vote for it.
the site for the whole time has been hash0 instead of a public key. 
So people can migrate to hash(n) and the network and history of hash0 won't be lost.
from here on link of the website will be hash(n) instead of a public key.
The network can split in this method.
I call this method consensusHash.

__________________________________________________________________________

Another suggestion is that site0 gets at least 10 authors. If 60% of authors agree to a change and sign it, the update will be injected to the network.
In this way if more than 40% of the authors discontinue their work the site would die.
Problem of disagreement amongst owners exists. It'll be like a senate.
The link would be hash0 for the whole time.
Owners list can be updated during a voting.
I call this method senateHash.

__________________________________________________________________________

This gives meaning to the life of Data, instead of Data being dependent on Authors keys.
Data will evolve to a BlockTree.

What do you think?

> [eightyfour](#comment_9_191jbK3GNmVritcMymKkFuxyYFXxqv2xpC): Doesn't Beaker/dat do something like that?

I don't know. I'm not a professional programmer yet.
Do you have any connections there? Thanks

Thanks @eightyfour.
Does anyone have "Get Games" Data?

1541600740_1P4KkC3wa5xtGD8m2MoBTf5p69G3X.body:
Selfishness, understood wisely, is the best moral ground I have found in my life.
If you are selfish, you avoid abusing people,
If you are selfish, you build on your credibility.

> [sheendocks](#comment_18_1P4KkC3wa5xtGD8m2MoBTf5p69G3Xr4aCU): I think I heard a satanist say something similar

Selfishness is inside any living being, written by DNA.

What I truly dislike, is seemingly selfless people expecting you to be selfless for them.
It's a twisted and sick kind of selfishness.

> [atomiserxenolith](#comment_29_1CFQMjPvz8m5BHtMnGyE7tRktdQ69WwUSX): Agree. Writing this immorality into law in the form of taxation (extortion) is it's visible manifestation.

I couldn't.
Maybe this time I'll like it.
Freenet should connect to the server, after you have visited some files, again.
Freenet does that even for it's own default page and settings.

> [freeperson](#comment_31_1QJVjdwjqjGfFp6CtxzWTu19HRusPi9ds6): You could create a proxy server for freenet with caching if you like. Some might consider that a security risk though, since it will leave a record of what you recently visited.

That's complicated, and not in an interesting way. But ZeroNet is SEXY ;)
I tried to try i2p today, it didn't work out as well. I nearly spent 2 hours on it.

> [freeperson](#comment_32_1QJVjdwjqjGfFp6CtxzWTu19HRusPi9ds6): In my opinion the "sexiness" of ZeroNet is due to the nice UIs you can have. But this is a consequence of JavaScript, which significantly increases the attack surface. [...]

Some networks should be designed to be open for everyone.
How many hackers are there who can hide from everyone? Even those few know a mistake can expose them.
This network is designed to be easy.

1542278485_1ELQXPkiUPmfR2ZCJLyhEucP5vqkL.body:
> [styromaniac](#comment_306_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): Plz no.

I'm happy with it, for now.
It gets things done. The marketplace behind it runs its engines.
If FOSS network makes a patreon specifically for better design in free-software, It would change the tides.
I'm an Artist, so Design really matters to me. There is coherence in my OS.

> [styromaniac](#comment_311_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): Desktop environment diversity I think is fine. ...

The thing is, FOSS minded people are religious about diversity.
In nature there is a pattern of centralization, decentralization. It's the heartbeat of evolution, by Natural Selection or by Intelligent Design.

I haven't seen people coming together, focusing, choosing a leader, making exact purposes come to reality.
Some people say, that's part of the soul of FOSS; I totally disagree.

> [styromaniac](#comment_311_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): ... Cinnamon is very polished for those who came from Windows and need familiarity. ...

I hate windows. It doesn't have any structure, and fucks up your mind.
What about those who come from mac?
I have a powerful system from 2014, but with Mojave, apple has slowed down my system a little. I know they are gonna do it again each year.
If it slows down I'll either buy a new one or move to Arch.
By the way, Mojave dark mode is a really good move.

> [zeroforze](#comment_3_1MH6Mx8cxRRWFZEckKc8tztJGDyEBzri8H): If FOSS network makes a patreon specifically for better design [...]

I have a solution which I have been thinking about, and pruning again and again over the years.
I call it #UserStoryHub, it's a pragmatic version of #IDEAsPlatform.

> [eightyfour](#comment_21_191jbK3GNmVritcMymKkFuxyYFXxqv2xpC): for those who come from a mac there is Ubuntu and elementaryOS

They don't attract me. elementaryOS is nice, yet I prefer mac.
Although I have my problems with macOS.
The most important thing cyber space needs is a nice 'file Browser'. Not another file manager, browsing sites on the net are much more interesting than what's locally on your system.

I am a member of the network, feeling the need in here. I'm sure if we come up with a good proposal, the creator will listen to us. Though the decision is his in the end.
